Title.evidence: This randomised controlled trial investigated the impact of the timing of first massive transfusion (MT) cooler delivery on patient outcomes.

Trial_Design.evidence: patients predicted to require MT were randomised to two transfusion ratios (1:1:1 vs. 1:1:2)

Participants.evidence: Conducted at 12 level-1 trauma centers, patients predicted to require MT were randomised

Intervention.evidence: randomised to two transfusion ratios (1:1:1 vs. 1:1:2)

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial investigated the impact of the timing of first massive transfusion (MT) cooler delivery on patient outcomes.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was mortality, assessed at 24 hours and 30 days post-intervention.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was executed via a centralised system with concealed allocation.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not applicable to outcome assessors, patients, or clinicians.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 680 patients were randomised

Result_Outcome.evidence: Delays in MT activation and cooler delivery were significantly associated with prolonged time to hemostasis (coef 1.09, p=0.001 and coef 1.16, p<0.001) and increased mortality (OR 1.02, p=0.009 and OR 1.02, p=0.012).

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported in either group.
